ï»¿Execution Version Dated October 9, 2014 COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global In rastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is en ered into on October 9, 2014 between: (1) ENDEAVOR ENERGY HOLDINGS LLC, herein represented by its Chief Executive Officer headquartered at 1800 West oop South, Suite 1100 B, Houston, Texas 77027, USA ("Endeavor"); and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUF, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPIh E I7 ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), heacquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, USA , le INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvar i Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("MIGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, D( 133, USA (the "World Bank Group") (each a "Party" and together, the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad internationa recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Inter i it nal Organizations (lOs), the G77, and the private sector represented by the B20 that investin : ir the infrastructure of Emerging IVarkets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to q: 3nd access to basic services ano raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic r Nth targets. (B) Meeting this need presents a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on ci ing sources of infrastructure finaice-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and cooi d r ted effort is needed to mobilize p ivate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robt st pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects an, I th 3 is understood to be the greates: barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investm:i it (D) Governments, development finance institutions, donors, and private investors share an in en( t in developing the market for private infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand sc , in the numbers of structurally sound and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual em ice of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range o ri !ate investors that actively partic pate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals wil 1e iefit from collective action between this range of entities-to leverage resources and know1:; a to find solutions to complex i ifrastructure financing challenges that no single institutio<i : >uld achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, thE Parties propose the establishment of a Global InfrastructurE 1 ility Partnership Program ("GIF") The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at levera ii(- the efforts of the wide range of i istitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastruct .E with the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project pre rei ion, structuring, and risk mitigati n for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, :1e GIF aims to complement existinq and proposed services and initiatives currently supporte :, the Parties and other prospectiv! GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prepi ir iell- structured, infrastructure prc jects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for acces :i;i the expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from pro :liE tive private sector financiers into project structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater I no! age of official resources in the ft:ce of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular :- irge and complex projects with th B potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now intere,ted in collaborating in developing the Global InfrastructurE :i 'ility Partnership Program, togeth r with other partners. 2
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have come to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facilit I Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended to be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set ot t ir Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Foi ndational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the GIF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collat:xn on, they are of an indicative nature and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties and Nit other potential partners until tie GIF is formally established. The final version of these obje::'iK s and principles will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend to Nork together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to fuither enhance their coordination, in particular by developiig tt E IF, with a view to formally establi:hing the program by December 2014. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the foregoing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue tc collaborate in developing the 31F, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of collaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the rmles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each categor b. Governance arrangerients of the GIF; c. Operational policies epplicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activities and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to projE selection criteria and :oordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of ollaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, includ n; sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through th wu e of knowledge platforms for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finaliz ng the design of the GIF, the multilateral development bank li :ed in Annex 2 will be invited to participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF d( Eic is finalized, additional collabor3tive efforts are required to develop the operational details f:ii the GIF, at all times complemcnting existing efforts and facilities and building upon the s, -ed knowledge and experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the ia,r of coordination between the Parties and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration Ar angement is not a legally binding agreement or commitment Ib) le Parties to enter into or provido support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisic ns of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their commoi understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose al I gal obligations or liabilities on an Party. 3.2 This Collaboration Ar angement is valid and effective for a period of one year from t 'x date thereof, unless supersec ed at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect tl-at this document and information with respect to the collabor i1 v activities contemplated hereir will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' iespective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult witi : .h 3
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's suppor regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arranc ement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciatic r c other modification of any of t& e privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of th Parties under their constituent documents, international conventions and any applicable la- In witness whereof, each of the Part es has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be executEJ i1- two (2) counterparts of equal content 3nd form by a duly authorized representative of each Party a he date first set forth above. 4

ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, compr sing the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTIOI I 4HIiD DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By J ONG KIM, PRESIDEN- 6
ï»¿Execution Version Annex I Preliminary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the CIF is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure pi :, ts in emerging markets and devoloping economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparati Ir provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercia institutional investor engagerr ent in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex publ -private partnerships and projects with potential for commer :ia viability which require project oreparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastru t. financing solutions that no sirgle institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF c ims to create a global platform to provide financial and coorc ra! on resources in collaboration wit i the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of th i le range of donor and developm ent finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMDI infrastructure, with the input and ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engagemer t c: Ad stretch from upstream support on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to downstream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risk mitigation/credit enhancement. 1.3 Over the longer term, by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structure : infrastructure projects, the GI can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset cla.s attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking long :in i assets in faster growing econ )mies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment opp )rtunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profile;; 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to olerate according to the following core principles, to be finalizE JL On agreement among GIF partnE rs: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities tl a: , ill draw together co nparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing public goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly thosE infrastructure pro ects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sustainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to t lt practice standarcs for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, c Dmplementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing tE :11 cal and financial resources of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mul i: 'ral development inst tutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in an innovative and fl.xible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve greatE leverage and adc ress the complex infrastructure financing challenges that are beyond the resoL rces of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected :o involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in tl E development and implementE,tion of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF pE rin: rs are expected to fall into one c r more of the following categories: 7
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partneis-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF wi I considered Fund ng Partners. (ii) Technical Partnlrs-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice and support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-fLinde : activities and/or F rovision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity suppc ri instruments. (iii) Advisory Partners-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and/or institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sove eign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as wE l1 other multilateral or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure pro ects, to be invited into discussions related to project prepara In optimal approaches to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, with a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/or institutional inves:ment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Council is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic prograrrmin management and use of fund 3, and development of operational policies and procedures; 1:1 hold the GIF Management Ur it (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility's objectives and principles, wit[ advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The compot cz of the Governing Council will be agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is propc s . to comprise representatives of F unding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Council comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing DirE c:c and Chief Financial Officer of the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facilil it e coordination of GIF activities -ind support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve :V; sounding board, providing gu dance and support for GIF Management, and in particular wi h E view to ensuring suitability of )rojects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be admiristered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicatec i: :n established for this purpose (the GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will fu -et n as a coordinating body as prciects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then mov:, toward technical support and financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead inc i\ id ial projects. 4.2 GIF activity implemer tation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partnei institutions, coordinated by th e GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governmel t;, according to specific project r:equirements and the project origination processes. Composi i(r :f the implementation teams mEy vary according to the need of individual projects and gover -1 n nts. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection criteria and processes could be developed to reflect the follow irc principles: (i) Development Impact-projects that support the development goals of the Gll partner institutions; (ii) Alignment-proj cts that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities ic strategies; (iii) Complexity-prc jects that require multiple parties to come together to providE structuring, arran:jing and financial support, and/or projects which require a bl r d >f financial instrumE nts; and 8
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impaci -projects that have significant potential to achieve financial i1 lity, leverage public ft nds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors- I as through Public-Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's ser ice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastrt cture investments that have global public good characteristic ;o ich as climate friendly-projects that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provisior c f infrastructure services; and tride enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconnet t wi and trade. 5.2 The scope of suppoAt provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with I vi w to complementing the resources and support already available from partner entities and ot e r funding mechanisms. During he GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following ac 'ii s, corresponding to major project development stages: (i) Project definition 3nd enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; proj ect definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility scri E ig; and legal, regulatbry, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparaticn and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and PF P structuring; (iii) Transaction support and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, and design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arranging and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financi '(I packages from a *ange of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies-i icluding in particular the management of environmental and c cl impacts and risks, and transp 3rency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastrt et- a projects in supporting sustain 3ble, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, *eputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supported operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements 1: external implementing entities under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an ap roach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards and c :1 r standards and policies, and dvelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for GI Technical Partners who are e(pected to function as implementing entities for GIF activities 9
